TOKENS: p e a ɟ a
NOTES: Only the numerals for ‘one’ and ‘two’ are originally from Cavineña. The remaining numerals, from ‘three’ to ‘ten’, have been borrowed from Aymara. (Cavineña1[492])

TOKENS: b e t a
k i m i ɕ a
p ʊ ɕ i
p i ɕ i k a
ɕ ʊ k ʊ t a
p a + k a r ʊ k ʊ
NOTES: pa stems from Aymara paja 'two' > pa

TOKENS: k i m i s/ɕ a + k a r ʊ k ʊ
NOTES: karʊkʊ stems from Aymara qaʎqu, a bound morpheme meaning 'five'

TOKENS: p ʊ s/ɕ -/i + k ʊ/a r ʊ k ʊ
t ʊ ŋ k a
p e a ɟ a + t ʊ ŋ k a + p e a ɟ a + e a r a k a n a
NOTES: As pointed out by Cavineña1[496] the translation of earakana as 'unit' is tentative
